title: Trochodendron
text:
Trochodendron is a genus of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s with one living species, "<a href="Trochodendron%20aralioides">Trochodendron aralioides</a>", and six extinct species known from the fossil record. It was often considered the sole genus in the family <a href="Trochodendraceae">Trochodendraceae</a>, though botanists now also include the distinct genus "<a href="Tetracentron">Tetracentron</a>" in the family.
Species.
"Trochodendron" is native to <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, southern <a href="Korea">Korea</a>, <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> and the <a href="Ryukyu%20Islands">Ryukyu Islands</a>, with fossils known from <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, and the Russian Far East.
"Trochodendron aralioides" is an <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> <a href="tree">tree</a> or large <a href="shrub">shrub</a> growing to 20 m tall. "Trochodendron" and "Tetracentron" lack <a href="vessel%20element">vessel element</a>s in their <a href="wood">wood</a>, a quite unusual feature in <a href="flowering%20plant">angiosperms</a>. This has long been considered a very primitive character, resulting in the classification of these two genera in a basal position in the angiosperms; however, genetic research by the <a href="Angiosperm%20Phylogeny%20Group">Angiosperm Phylogeny Group</a> has shown it to be in a less basal position (early in the <a href="eudicot">eudicot</a>s), suggesting the absence of vessel elements in these two genera is a secondarily evolved character, not a primitive one.
Fossil record.
Among the middle <a href="Miocene">Miocene</a> <a href="Sarmatian%20%28age%29">Sarmatian</a> <a href="palynology">palynoflora</a> from the <a href="Lavanttal">Lavanttal</a> Basin <a href="Austria">Austria</a> researchers have recognized "Trochodendron" <a href="fossil">fossil</a> <a href="pollen">pollen</a>. The sediment containing the "Trochodendron" fossil pollen had accumulated in a lowland wetland environment with various vegetation units of mixed evergreen/deciduous broadleaved/conifer forests surrounding the wetland basin. Key relatives of the fossil taxa found with "Trochodendron" pollen are presently confined to humid warm temperate environments, suggesting a <a href="subtropical">subtropical</a> climate during the middle Miocene in Austria.
